title: Do you accept LGBTQ teens? - Quora

response.answer_text: LGBT+ teenagers and other LGBT people spend so much time & energy trying to fit-in to our heterosexual society and yet everything they do *sets them apart!* Asking questions like this one, makes it seem like ALL of you want is to be accepted and treated as everyday, ordinary people. Teenagers, can do and be whatever they want in 2020, but yet everything YOU do seems like a huge CONTRADICTION to your end game. LGBT+ why do you set yourselves apart from everyone else? Why the added stigma of “We are LGBT+ and proud?”  As a born and raised heterosexual person, who’s sex and gender MATCH, I would think that in an effort to be included with us ordinary, boring heterosexual folks, you would NOT be announcing all of your indignation to the world and then standing back, wondering why (some) people still have a problem with your EXISTENCE? I accept ALL people, whether they be men, women, children, seniors, lesbian, gay, bi-sexual, transsexual, purple, green or orange whatever. Take a look at what LGBT+ is doing world wide and then ask yourself, WHY some people still have a problem accepting YOU as one of the ordinary, boring public?

Well to me to accept them is to encourage their behavior which for me i don't on a religious point of view I know not many will agree with online However, I do tolerate what they do. I'm not against them because in the end I could at least grasp where they are coming from and that in the end I can't tell them nor force them to be something they believe they aren't because the would need to conform to my beliefs. (ironic since LGBTQ adults seem to be doing something similar to children here in the US) I don't support what they believe in but I don't want to be in the way of allowing them to do it anyway. I simply don't care and I don't think theu should either becaise the only important validation they need is from themselves not the entire earth's population. So yeah I don't accept them I do tolerate them but in the end why two cents about them isnt worth much nor should it to someone who truly cares about their own personal identity.

Yes, unless they start shoving it in my face. getting offended at every single lgbtq thing said, and if they start trying to get me to read and watch LGBTQ stuff like jackspetic eye x markiplier type stuff or whatever than no as a person I will not accept you. I had a friend who is apart of the lgbtq community and she always shoved it in my face to the point where if I said I didn't want to read any of her LGBTQ fan fiction she accused me of being homophobic. But I know not everyone is like this so sexuality doesnt matter to me as long as you dont suck as a person

It's not up to me to accept, or not, anyone else's sexuality. When I was a teenager, way back in the stone age, most teenagers were struggling to find their way in the confusing world of hormones and sexuality. Then, as now, most teenagers were experimenting, sneaking peeks at adult magazines, reading anything we could get our hands on regarding sex (even if some of it was unrealistic--kama sutra anyone?). Too many kids, now as then, are going to claim whatever is “popular” with their peers. I knew several, back in the day, that claimed to be sexually active, because it was “uncool” if you weren't, and they were really virgins. In my son's high school years, they would often say they were bisexual because that was the “it” thing, even though as adults they're either totally straight, or totally gay. I think labeling a kid's sexuality before they become a self reliant, functioning adult, is doing them an injustice. They're just learning about themselves and the world. Let them, as we used to say, find themselves. There's no need to rush it.

Not usually; very few of them can afford my fees. I don’t know that I’ve ever had a teen client … Oh, you mean accept them as people? What a silly question! What rational reason would there be not to accept them?

upvoters.user_id: a person you probably dont know

response.answer_text: Why would you not? They are born that way just as you and I are born heterosexual. It’s not a choice, it’s pre programmed. It’s who they are. Why would you wish them to have to live a lie their whole lives? Would you want someone to force you to be a lesbian if you weren’t or have a sex change if you didn’t want to? What’s the difference. None! Let them be, a little acceptance please. Tolerance and love please. It will save many from suicide believe me!

YOu lump all these together like they had anything to do with each other. Lesbians and gay guys… obviously exist…. so too, do teens. Bisexuals…. that’s complicated…. having a mutual wank in the toilets. or touching through trousers etc is normal exploration of sex and bodies… there may be bisexual teenagers. Transgender is such a wide thing these days…. there are certainly teenagers - a few - who honestly believe they were born in the wrong sex, and want to change, they are transexuals…. but there’s a whole raft of others who are just making a statement that they reject the stereotypical idea of man and woman. It’s a bit of a trend at the moment, but I respect them for breaking down differences… but not anything to do with sexuality. Q? Who knows what that is. One thing that is always missing in the urge to change or fluidize or genderbend is guys never mention anything to do with children - the main difference between sexes….nobody questions why their parental role is not the equivalent of female.

Now I'm a teen myself. I know. It's rather damning to be a normal teen these days, let alone a teen that is from a minority segment of the population. But the fact that they are not accepted by the general populace does not mean in the slightest that we should not accept them. In fact, we should accept them more. For they are still homo sapiens sapiens and a part of us. By ostracizing a particular person in society, you are also ostracizing yourself from him. Segregation works both ways. The LGBTQ teen you refused to tutor may go on to find a cure for the type of cancer your mom is suffering from. The LGBTQ teen you refused to allow your child be friends with may go on to become the POTUS. The LGBTQ teen that was never given a chance in life, when finally presented with one, will lunge at it and grab it like someone in the desert thirsts for water. And woe betide what he/she does with this opportunity. Because LGBTQs have a harder path, they will be more resilient, more hard-working and more prudent than others. Faced with an obstacle, they will push at it harder than others, who may not even try. In the end, while that so-called “perverted and dirty mind” goes on to achieve success, those who discriminate them will only have the privilege of watching from afar.

I do. I don’t feel it’s my place to bible shame people into committing suicide. I would never be so presumptuous as to speak for Jesus Christ but others don’t seem to mind. If the teens in question aren’t hurting anyone I don’t see how it’s anyone’s business.

Of course I do. I was an LGBTQ teen growing up in the Midwest back in the 1960–1990, when being LGBTQ could get you killed. I accept all LGBTQ teens because I wasn’t. I want them to know they are accepted and loved.

I struggle with questions like this. Because the real answer is that I don’t accept them. But not because of the reasons that immediately jump to mind. I don’t accept them because there is nothing to accept. They are who they are. They like who they like. There is nothing to accept. That is the way things are. Not accepting that is to deny reality.
Of course. People in groups subjected to discrimination and prejudice may be especially in need of a listening ear and suspension of judgment. I’ve been mentoring kids for over 40 years.

Of course I do! Not only do I follow a few teens on here that are, but my little sister is also. I accept everyone for who they are, but if they mess up our friendship very badly, or are toxic people, then I won't like or care too much about them in all honesty.

Yes. I was born as a heterosexual, cisgender girl. They weren't. I can't understand what they're going through because I've never gone through it, but I'm not going to hold anything against them. I don't care what someone does as long as they don't hurt/violate anyone.

Of course, especially since teenage years can be a confusing time. Whether they are 100% certain or not, their sexuality can change all through life and if people don’t accept who teenagers are attracted to, then the teens could easily just shut themselves out from the world. It’s important to accept them for who they are, without exception when it comes to LGBT.
Yes. I accept LGBTQ+ teens. They are valid human beings that should be accepted. Plenty of queer kids don’t get much unconditional love and I’d love to be there for them.
Yes. Definitely yes. Yes. And yes. Look, I basically see no problem with being LGBTQ+. Why wouldn’t I accept it? Also, my best friend is LGBT+. ok. so yes. still yes. cya in the next answer, Heidi :D

It depends. If countries/societies are not able to accept Polyamorous people by making Polygamy LEGAL, then maybe those countries/societies might not accept LGBTQ as well If you think not accepting LGBTQ which occurs naturally in all animals is a bad thing, then think of how shocking it is when a society BANS polygamy even though Polyamorous people happen naturally and those people would need a contract from the government so that the children born out of polygamous relationships are not treated as orphans
Yes I do I am bi my son bestfriend is gay.
Of course I do! The majority of my friends are in the LGBTQ community. I love them. They're some of the best people I know.
Yes
Yes.
